An hour into the game, Iâ€™m mad at myself for not starting this Metroidvania game sooner.

This game looks and feels great!

items.title: New music out from Zeal & Ardor
items.content_html:
This morning I woke up and saw an alert on my phone that there where a new song called â€œTuskegee from Zeal & Ardor out on Apple Music.

The track itself is amazing. I’ve listened to it on repeat for the last hour.

I quickly found out that the track is from the upcoming EP Wake of a Nation.

And not only that, two more tracks “I can’t Breathe” and â€œVigilâ€ had also been released.

With lyrics like â€œI can’t breathe, it’s a cellphone, please don’t shootâ€ and â€œI need to get home, I’m on my knees begging pleaseâ€ I guess there is no prize for guessing the theme of this EP.

This is a strong contender for the best record of the year for me. Even though I’ve only heard three out of six songs of the EP.
items.content_text:
This morning I woke up and saw an alert on my phone that there where a new song called â€œTuskegee from [Zeal & Ardor](https://www.zealandardor.com) out on Apple Music.

The track itself is amazing. I've listened to it on repeat for the last hour.

I quickly found out that the track is  from the upcoming EP [Wake of a Nation](https://zealandardor.bandcamp.com/album/wake-of-a-nation-ep). 

And not only that, two more tracks "I can't Breathe" and â€œVigilâ€ had also been released. 

With lyrics like â€œI can't breathe, it's a cellphone, please don't shootâ€ and â€œI need to get home, I'm on my knees begging pleaseâ€ I guess there is no prize for guessing the theme of this EP.

This is a strong contender for the best record of the year for me. Even though I've only heard three out of six songs of the EP.

items.title: Norway closing down
items.content_html:
As all schools and kindergartens closed in Norway yesterday, I’m today at home with my three kids. The work my wife does has been deemed critical by the government, so she’s at work.

I work for a company that creates an LMS. An LMS that has millions of users. Users that are moving to being online doing school work all day, instead of just parts of the day.

Which means all the performance improvements that I’ve been working on for work, suddenly became more important.

So here I am, at home, with three kids, and desperately wanting to help out at work but can’t.

At least not as much as I’d like.

Strange times this.
items.content_text:
As all schools and kindergartens closed in Norway yesterday, I'm today at home with my three kids. The work my wife does has been deemed critical by the government, so she's at work.

I work for a company that creates an LMS. An LMS that has millions of users. Users that are moving to being online doing school work _all_ day, instead of just parts of the day.

Which means all the performance improvements that I've been working on for work, suddenly became more important.

So here I am, at home, with three kids, and desperately wanting to help out at work but can't. 

At least not as much as I'd like.


Strange times this.

> Goal: Be at least 20% faster than your fastest competitor.

items.title: Building the most inaccessible site possible
items.content_html:
As someone who cares a lot about creating inclusive websites, Building the most inaccessible site possible with a perfect Lighthouse score by Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡ was an incredible read.

I have lost count of how often a coworker points to their Lighthouse score as â€œproofâ€ that their page is accessible.

And I donâ€™t have anything against lighthouse, I use it myself. But itâ€™s only one of many steps you have to take to assure your page is inclusive.

items.title: Benign
items.content_html:
So for the second time this year I was back at the hospital this week. For months now I’ve been having brief periods of vertigo. Last week it became so bad it I was unable to be upright for a whole day.

After a visit to my doctor he had a suspicion that is was Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.

I was sent to the hospital to rule out all the scary stuff and see if they could figure it out.

Many nauseating tests later, the doctors concluded that it was indeed BPPV.

Luckily it wasn’t anything dangerous, and it should be resolved in a couple of weeks.

But this whole incident reminded me again how happy I am to pay my taxes and have a well functioning health system.
items.content_text:
So for the second time this year I was back at the hospital this week. For months now I've been having brief periods of vertigo. Last week it became so bad it I was unable to be upright for a whole day. 

After a visit to my doctor he had a suspicion that is was [Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benign_paroxysmal_positional_vertigo).

I was sent to the hospital to rule out all the scary stuff and see if they could figure it out.

Many nauseating tests later, the doctors concluded that it was indeed BPPV.

Luckily it wasn't anything dangerous, and it should be resolved in a couple of weeks.

But this whole incident reminded me again how happy I am to pay my taxes and have a well functioning health system.

items.title: Inside
items.content_html:
I finished the game Inside yesterday on my Switch. I’ve had Inside for both PS4 and iOS for some time, but never ended up playing it. I now wish I’d played it before.

It’s a great platform-puzzle game, with striking visuals and a sense of danger I hardly get from games anymore. I was unable to put it down once I started playing.

So if you like platform games with a dark sci-fi tone, this is the game for you.

items.title: WWDC by Sundell
items.content_html:
John Sundell of Swift by Sundell fame, is back with WWDC by Sundell.

This website is for everyone who wants to closely follow WWDC, but from anywhere in the world. Starting right now, this site will be updated daily with articles, videos, podcasts, and interviews, covering all things WWDC â€” from recommendations on what session videos to watch, to in-depth looks at new APIs, to interviews with people from all over the Apple developer community.

So far I’ve been reading the articles and listened to the podcasts, and enjoyed myself.

As I’m waiting for WWDC next week this will be a great site to keep watching.

items.title: Svelte 3
items.content_html:
My favourite javascript library, Svelte, was just upgraded to version 3.

If you don’t know Svelte, it is a component framework â€” like React or Vue. But running at build time instead of at run time.

After several months of being just days away, we are over the moon to announce the stable release of Svelte 3. This is a huge release representing hundreds of hours of work by many people in the Svelte community, including invaluable feedback from beta testers who have helped shape the design every step of the way.

We think you’re going to love it.

Be sure to read Svelte 3: Rethinking reactivity, the announcement post from @Rich Harris, and then jump over to the Svelte tutorial.
items.content_text:
My favourite javascript library, [Svelte](https://svelte.dev), was just upgraded to version 3.

If you don't know Svelte, it is a component framework â€” like React or Vue. But running at build time instead of at run time. 

> After several months of being just days away, we are over the moon to announce the stable release of Svelte 3. This is a huge release representing hundreds of hours of work by many people in the Svelte community, including invaluable feedback from beta testers who have helped shape the design every step of the way.

> We think you're going to love it.


Be sure to read [Svelte 3: Rethinking reactivity](https://svelte.dev/blog/svelte-3-rethinking-reactivity), the announcement post from [@Rich Harris](https://twitter.com/Rich_Harris), and then jump over to the [Svelte tutorial](https://svelte.dev/tutorial).

items.title: Independent Web
items.content_html:
When I read Designing with Web Standards by Jeffrey Zeldman it felt life-altering. It totally changed my view on web development. (As I believe it has done for many developers.)

I got back to work fired up with ideas of how we could create better software using semantic html. And we did.

15 years later Iâ€™m still passionate about creating great accessible software for the web. But Iâ€™m surprised I still have to convince other developers that we have to use semantic html.

In Nothing Fails Like Success Zeldman talks about the complicated relationship between money and tech on the web.

And asks the question if IndieWeb can save us?

I â¤ï¸ the movement, and hope to use Micro.blog for a very long time.

And hopefully piece by piece we can create the parts needed to never hear words like â€œletâ€™s just put up a Facebook pageâ€ again.
items.content_text:
When I read [Designing with Web Standards](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Designing_with_Web_Standards) by [Jeffrey Zeldman](http://www.zeldman.com/) it felt life-altering. It totally changed my view on web development. (As I believe it has done for many developers.)

I got back to work fired up with ideas of how we could create better software using semantic html. And we did.

15 years later Iâ€™m still passionate about creating great accessible software for the web. But Iâ€™m surprised I still have to convince other developers that we have to use semantic html.

In [Nothing Fails Like Success](https://alistapart.com/article/nothing-fails-like-success/) Zeldman talks about the complicated relationship between money and tech on the web.

And asks the question if [IndieWeb](https://indieweb.org/) can save us?

I â¤ï¸ the movement, and hope to use [Micro.blog](https://micro.blog/) for a very long time.

And hopefully piece by piece we can create the parts needed to never hear words like â€œletâ€™s just put up a Facebook pageâ€ again.
